review_title: Flexible working but incompetent middle management
job_title: Office Administrator in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Flexible working - hybrid working and flexi time on offer. Good annual leave allowance and sick pay/employee benefits.
cons: A lot of staff in lower management positions who have inexplicably progressed to where they are , who are aware of their own incompetence and lord over staff to justify their job titles. Very little forward-thinking or strategic planning, and lip service is paid to staff wellbeing but that's where it ends. Very few progression opportunities are available for younger ambitious staff, and appointments to higher grade vacancies are appointed to in such a predictable way that people just stop applying.

job_title: Accounts Payable in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Good for Research and study.
cons: The accounts payable managers are bullies. You can work for much better managers anywhere else. The team manager would shout and even use foul language during meetings with staff. Data produced by the managers could quite often appear as incorrect and again if anyone raised this issue, rather than dealing with it properly the manager would actually just get aggressive. Staff quite often are belittled and bullied. Several previous team members were bullied and eventually quit/moved teams but too afraid to speak up. Avoid the accounts payable team.

job_title: Research Associate in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Location of the Newcastle University
Living in Newcastle
Meeting some great people in and outside of workplace
cons:
I need to make it clear that this is based on my personal experience during my work in Newcastle University within a team which has been managed  poorly and unprofessionally creating a very stressful and toxic environment. 
As a scientist and researcher  I am responsible to carry out my research scientifically and accurately making sure of having appropriate and sufficient quality control measures.  I found it extremely difficult and unscientific that my line manager, a senior scientist, expected me to produce a result to prove her proposed theory rather than genuine result to test and validate the theory .
Also, I had to report and send my results to a person who previously worked with my line manager as a PhD student but at the time of my employment had no position in university, her role within our team was never explained and I never got even a single constructive comment from her. 
Colleagues in our team were treated differently, unprofessional language and behaviour was used by the line manager including patronising, bullying and  talking behind the colleagues who were left the team and accusing them of misconduct without any evidence. The list of unprofessional behaviours is a long list which I have no intention to fill this space with.

review_title: friendly people, freedom to work on own project, but invisible line manager (group has no vision)
job_title: Research Associate in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
I am given freedom to work on my own projects, colleagues are friendly, and there is cross-departmental collaboration going on.

I have been encouraged to apply for my own funding, but I am not convinced that this is what I want. The personal career advise service was helpful, though.
cons:
- People are squeezed into noisy open plan offices and expected to perform optimally. This is not only at my own department, but at multiple departments across the university.
- IT facilitates are insufficient: The university e-mail account is only 2Gb. IT problems usually take months to be fixed.
- My post-doc salary is low (£28k) and there is no opportunity to earn extra money in my department.
- Some of the buildings (not all) are old and dusty, make sure you see your work environment before you take up a job

review_title: Good office, but destined to be in admin forever if I'd stayed!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newcastle, England
pros:
This particular office that I worked within wasn't without its 'office politics' at times, but in general had a very good atmosphere and great team, which I felt full involved in.
Senior staff were personable as were academic staff.
Flexible working time and easy to get holiday approved if sent ahead of time and not at a busy time of year for your programme.
Easy environment to work within if you are flexible.
cons:
In the role I was in, the admin support take on a large bulk of the grunt work, which I personally hate - it makes me feel as though I'm 'just the admin' and as though I don't have any skills of use!
No real progression - once you're in the University it is very easy to get other jobs within the University, but not so easy to actually get higher pay/a different role - I felt like I would have forever remained an admin assistant although the role was varied.
Office politics, because, duh.  It sucks but it pretty much happens, these places breed ill feeling when people get bored/despondent.

job_title: Research Assistant in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Central location, nice, smart, people to work with. Your schedule and experience would depend on the PI - mine was reasonable, encouraging, and very good to work with. Also very supportive of future plans, helped me get into a great PhD program. Good mouse facility - very helpful staff.
cons:
Institute was off-campus so less interaction with the Medical school and other departments and more standalone. 

University/ Institute seems to have harmful practices when it comes to publishing research - favoring high-impact journals and if not, not publishing at all, in order to improve the REF scores I guess. This can stall careers and is toxic!

job_title: PhD Student in Newcastle, England
pros:
It has a 5* RAE rating and is a beautiful city to work. Housing and cost of living is relatively low compared with other UK cities and it has easy access to international airports, rail and main roads.
The University has very modern research facilities with state-of-the-art equipment.
cons:
There is no recommended or advised holiday system for students - I had one week off in total over a 4 year period and this was deemed acceptable.
There is very little support structure in place for students outside their Supervisor. If this relationship breaks down its a general attitude of 'tough'.
There is very little support from Supervisors to complete extra curricular activities, so to speak, to broaden employability and commercial awareness even though these activities are seemingly encouraged by the department as a whole.

review_title: Honorary Senior Clinical lecturer/Degree Programme Director
job_title: Senior Clinical Lecturer/Programmer Director in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
A fantastic place to work with a true collaborative and learning culture - as you would imagine within a University! However - it is a privilege to work with such bright, enthusiastic and supportive colleagues and I think this is actually rather rare these days?
We are completely student centric and the post grad students who we teach are a fabulous bunch who equally give us extremely positive feedback in terms of the quality of teaching and their learning experience.
cons:
The pay is not fantastic in terms of the amount of skills and knowledge that staff have however the psychological contract is, as discussed above - very positive and high. This outweighs the lack of high salaries in my eyes.
There is a huge amount of bureaucratic paperwork which seems disproportionately high?

job_title: in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Good support for research grants, medium-sized institution, cost of living in the area is quite low, uni is in the centre of town and therefore easy to get to
cons: The uni used to be quite gentile and pleasant, but is now becoming ever more like a panopticon, and there is mounting pressure on staff to generate research income. Stingy with salaries. Dedicated to raising performance in rankings, hence everything gets skewed toward that goal. Hard to get internal promotion to top level (personal chair).

job_title: Student Ambassador in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Great University with great support. Lots of training to help you through your jobs. Pretty good salary for doing pretty easy work if it communicating with people comes naturally to you. Many shifts are available.
cons: Sometimes lectures cover the available jobs so it is hard to find times to do them and university work often mounts up. Sometimes it can be tedious if you are just sign posting people to events but it is good pay for little effort so absolutely can not complain.

job_title: Research Assistant in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Very smart and friendly people in the teaching and research fields. 
This place is very good for networking.
Good access to facilities and other resources. 
Newcastle is one of the best places to live in the UK.
Good sport facilities.
cons:
Administration is slow, with some incompetent people and instead of helping they are providing additional hurdles for the research and teaching staff. 
Parking places are few and expensive.  
Sometimes lab and desk space are insufficient resulting in overcrowded laboratories and offices.
Food that can be bought within the campus is expensive and of very low quality. Better bring lunch from home.

job_title: Jobs On Campus in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Worked as a student temp worker while studying there, varied roles included cleaning, bar work, catering and office work. This allowed me to develop a wide range of skills. You meet many interesting people and the managers at the different roles are all welcoming and happy to offer help/guidance. It is temping work and so it is easy to choose when and for how long you would like to work (for example the holidays, on evenings, wednesday afternoons etc).
cons: It can be difficult joining a team in the middle of a project only for a couple of days as it doesn't give you enough of a chance to get to know people.

job_title: Reader in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: A highly respected research intensive university with a good stable management team and relatively few (at least in my school) top down restructuring initiatives. Very good students - particularly at undergraduate level in my discipline.
cons: Metics heavy with  tendency to micromanage from some university managers. Because Newcastle is outside the top 100 world universities it struggles to recruit hight quality masters students in some disciplines.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Newcastle University provides an excellent environment for research and teaching. Given that mental health problems in researchers are higher than regular population, the University has put the needs of research students first by providing training for supervisors with pastoral care responsibilities to identify mental health problems in their wards. They are also providing access to counselling, avenues for taking care of ones mental wellbeing.
cons: Due to the recent regrouping of 7 focused institutes within the Medical School into 3 broad institutes, the research talks published over email seem to misaligned with the audience.

review_title: Great for admins, ok for techs
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Excellent benefits - pension, flexible time, working hours, annual days of leave. The location in the centre of Newcastle upon Tyne is also great.
cons: Salaries are averageish in admin jobs, lower than average in technical fields. Research and academic positions have a national scale and so aren't completely under their control.

job_title: Student Ambassador in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Everything. Pay is well above the minimum wage, free breakfast and lunch is provided with some shifts, the supervisors are friendly and approachable, you work with other students (sometimes your own friends) and the work itself is very enjoyable. No stress at all.
cons: I cannot think of any cons for the role. My only dissatisfaction was the 20 weekly hours student visa restriction that prevented me from taking additional shifts.

job_title: Graduate Ambassador in Newcastle, England
pros: Good teams and leadership, with opportunities for progression and good staff development opportunities with regular reviews. Friendly atmosphere. Decent benefits and opportunities to travel, reasonable holiday allowance and good flexitime arrangements.
cons: Temporary year-long contracts for some roles, whilst ideal in many ways, made development of ideas difficult in some areas. One team settles in and finds their feet, then develops a few new ideas about how to improve procedures, but moves on fairly quickly so ideas can sometimes end up only half introduced.

job_title: in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Working with some hot technology, lots of input to processes.  Anyone can become a sought-after expert.  Friendly place with good people.
cons: budgets for hardware/software are adequate, no more.  quite political and there are rather a lot of people who think they know best but don't.  The IT Service does not enjoy a great reputation throughout the University.

review_title: Newcastle University, not the best research environment
job_title: Research Associate in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Friendly environment, less pressure compare to top  tier universities in UK, situated in a nice city with an affordable living costs considering the academic salaries
cons: Not the best research environment, specially in the field of engineering, the investment is more towards the new building and administrative staff than towards attracting high-quality academic/research staff, not offering a good program of career development for researchers, business-people-led type of management instead of academic-led type of management

job_title: Research Assistant in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Good team spirit. Freedom to do research at own pace (on day to day basis). Good laboratory facilities. Nice lifestyle on campus and good group of colleagues. Newcastle is a good city to live as well. Training and travel opportunities as University is very active in the international research network.
cons: A little weary environment and equipment. Compensation could always be better, especially as good flats are expensive.

job_title: Professional Support Services in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: I love working here.  It's right in the City Centre so it's easy to get to by bus, metro or train.  The holidays are generous with a closure period over Christmas and New Year.  The family friendly leave is also good and I feel I have a good work life balance.  Everyone is really friendly.
cons: Car parking isn't great in the City Centre

job_title: PhD Student in Newcastle, England
pros: Freedom of thought and effective tutoring with self development workshops, extensive facilities with an open mind to purchasing relevant equipment if required
cons: Pay is below industry however this is common within the industry. Some supervisors can be difficult however This was through word of mouth.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newcastle, England
pros: Good place to work, possibilities for the future and connection to industry. Good students and possibilities to be promoted. It' ok
cons: Nothing serious really. Good place to work, possibilities for the future and connection to industry. Good students and possibilities to be promoted. It' ok

review_title: Good company to work for. Decent pay and decent opportunities
job_title: Strengths Lab Technician in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Great working hours and convenient to commute to. Benefits are OK, option to pay year travel in installments off pay for example. Decent pay, could be better though. Always something new going on.
cons: As mentioned, pay could be better along with the benefits option. Own personal experience has shown it's difficult to move up the pay grades.

review_title: Best student job at the best University in England
job_title: Student Ambassador in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Friendly, collegiate atmosphere that encourages you to grow while supporting your growth, during studying!
Work is offered and accepted on an ad-hoc basis which makes work-study balance easier!
cons: Becoming a graduate and being ineligible for this job is the only reason I am no longer in this job, but I loved every second of it!

review_title: I gave my all to Newcastle when I did my marking and my teaching and what did I get back? Below minimum wage & no thanks
job_title: Marker/Teacher in Newcastle, England
pros: It has been an opportunity to give so much of value to undergraduates, PGTs and PGRs - in stimulating their thinking, challenging them, yet also learning much from them, too, in fact, as teaching is a dialogic engagement, at its best. It also enabled me to gain certain new skills and a further experience of teaching, lecturing and marking in academia. I love to teach and to add value to student experience, despite being undervalued, in reality, except in terms of some complimentary words that ultimately meant little and seem now to have been offered only to extract more work and value from me for so little remuneration - at least that is now the strong perception, as I piece my history teaching here at Newcastle together: the sad fragments that are now left. This is also the case with others, too, however, as many postgraduate researchers find themselves in such a situation where their labour is barely remunerated and thus objectively hardly valued. Lecturers, too, have often confided such to me as well, both in terms of the good and also in terms of the bad. The reason I mention some bad here is because even the pros have sucked me in to gain more value from me - work gone spectacularly unremunerated by me here at Newcastle. So, to be truthful in the truest way, the pros even have been used as cons. In this institutional context, alas. Hence why I mention them here, too, then!
cons:
Academia - and at Newcastle, this is so, too - is becoming more and more like a sausage factory - process the work quickly and efficiently, no matter how deeply and excellently one manages to feed back. Into the bargain, one will not be valued in a truly fair and rewarding financial way. I put so many hours including vast amounts of effort into my work and for what? No commendation at the end of it, some fine words on the way while I was needed and in relation to the past, yet once my term came to an end, what? Very little indeed and some might say a big fat nothing - with no final words of thanks (for my work is probably more or less all done). Work-life balance is hard when you are expected to do a really good or even a brilliant job within very strict deadlines. One can end up almost killing oneself, what with the other commitments of a busy researcher, too. Pay has also not gone up for postgraduate workers for a number of years (or, if it has, by hardly anything and from a low base). This is also the case for full lecturers and other staff, too, while senior management award themselves very high pay rises. This I consider outrageous. Who adds value by teaching the students, by marking, by even giving lectures? And for what? I had been proud to work for Newcastle University and saw myself as doing a grand job, until, that is, I felt undervalued and realised that I had put in all too much and got so little back in return. Vulnerable staff who are deeply committed will be used and the maximum of exploitation will be extracted from them/us. And it is systemic, with PGRs paid at a very low rate especially in terms of those who have prior lecturing experience (but this is not an argument for a tired pay structure, but for more rigorous training!). 

Academia deserves to be better than this. And I for one am very disappointed. UCU needs to look into these questions far more systematically, too, and try to help PGRs and other workers in vulnerable positions to improve their pay and their levels of support to each other - a culture of co-operation needs to be developed - by UCU as well as by the University. Why is this not happening? Does one wonder why UCU membership seems to be declining and dissatisfaction with the university increasing in the mood music behind closed doors of staff - of the best and most committed staff often? If no or little action is taken and no consistent and principled fight launched to rectify this situation, why would people wish to remain in such unions or indeed in Newcastle University? I am of course a member of UCU as well as ideally proud to be associated with teaching and training at Newcastle University. On the basis of high principle and fairness, I have engaged in strike action, for example, but the organisation of UCU, albeit it (its members) of course has good intentions, needs to be more than a mere talking shop with little bite behind it. Leadership within UCU, nationally and in local branches, then, is crucial, but more or as importantly as that, much leadership is required from Newcastle University as an organisation to make its workplace a good and a happy one, full of the joys of teaching, learning and development of all for all: not a top-down culture, but an inclusive and co-operative one that evens out and smooths out all invidious remuneration differentials is needed. For that, the Vice-Chancellor and senior management should keep their own pay right down (yes, endure some real cuts and share the distribution of a healthy pie more fully and widely) and not turn universities into cut and thrust big businesses and in doing so, deprave and dissipate our intellectual and academic culture in a de facto philistine direction. Sharing and co-operation are essential to this new culture I am urging upon management, which will re-incentivise the vast majority of staff, if implemented substantially. 

We need to change and accentuate co-operation before so much of the richesse disappears down the vast bottomless pits of pay packets for the top ten percent or so, as compared with feeble, virtually non-existent rises for the vast majority of workers at Newcastle University and this means on all levels, not just for academic or part-time academic staff (cleaners and their conditions of work are a real case in point: how an organisation treats the most vulnerable of workers in its midst tells one much about an organisation and there are all kinds of inequities and unfairnesses that cleaners have raised with me before, such as: when someone is off sick, the cleaners who nonetheless still come to work must take up the slack of the workers who are absent, with no extra remuneration or pay for overtime or the like; this is poor practice indeed and it should be stopped and another system adopted; perhaps others could be asked to come in and offered the work instead - for favourable rates of pay, or the staff who do come in that day might be offered higher remuneration and compensation for that extra work needing to be undertaken, yet it is a problem that happens again and again at Newcastle University and cleaners often complain justly of this unfair extra burden). 

Another kind of education is possible, for otherwise, all the best people in academia (as well as good support workers) will be driven away and all that will be left is the careerist types, senior management or higher bureaucrats and the likely self-interested chancers who tend to dominate the top positions. Believe you me, I have discussed this unhappiness with a good number of fine academics here, too, and they absolutely agree with me. A fair portion of those are being driven away, little by little, yet seemingly ineluctably so! And many others are getting increasingly restless and disgruntled. What is being sown here, Newcastle University? 'Mene mene tekel u-pharsim' - thou art weighed in the balance and found wanting, are you not?

job_title: Senior Infrastructure Technician in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: They are flexible with your working hours and have good staff benefits
cons: the pay isn't as high as you would get in a commercial enterprise and the management don't appear to move with the times and listen to staff concerns

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Convenient, pretty good colleagues, interesting work. I imagine it's fairly similar to most other universities in that respect. They are fond of having representatives communicate with them from our group of part time workers. 

Good values; sustainability, etc.
cons:
Disappointing response when I complained about a male colleague harassing me.  
The pay isn't great either, but it's better than most jobs.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: The staff is very helpful and responsive.Student services are great and effective.
cons: The lecturers are very good and know very well about the subject they are teaching, but some have difficulties speaking english because they are not from the UK. I sometimes had difficulties to understand the lectures.

job_title: Postgraduate in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Many opportunities for collaborative work, exposure to world-leading research and equipment, and personal development. Great location of university buildings in the city centre.
cons: Slow-paced environment due to endless obstacles. Essential due to the nature of the organisation, but irritating at times. Lack of technical support staff.

job_title: Research Associate in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: None whatsoever. Surprised it was awarded Athena Swan when women are forced into work with no flexible working hours or support for families with children.
cons: You are only treated well if you work long hours, even if it doesn't mean you produce more. If you are single and childless and love to spend weekends drinking with your manager then this is an ideal place to work. Poor resources and women treated poorly. No support to families with children or those with disabilities

review_title: Nice to work for by system heavy
job_title: Project Manager in Alnwick, England
pros: Enjoyable workplace and good facilities
cons: bureaucratic, not loyal - my contract was renewed annually for three years (with summer break in between each issue) then just stopped without a by-you-leave when Covid19 struck.

job_title: Visitor Research in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Everybody believes in your work, you have all the wherewithal, you learn a lot and it's a really nice city.
cons: Nothing to say as Cons. It was a really grateful experience.

job_title: Student Ambassador in Newcastle, England
pros:
Good pay for the work
Rota based shifts to fit around University schedule, very flexible
Good variety of activities and workshops to carry out
Meet lots of new people since co-workers are fellow students
cons: Since it's rota based you might not always get the amount of hours or exact shifts that you want

job_title: Accounts Clerk in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Working for the Uni is the best decision I ever made.  The training opportunites are second to none, great ways to progress. working conditions are fantastic and staff are very polite and helpful
cons: If you want to progress you have to go for it, hard work pays off in the end

review_title: Interesting and varied work with the opportunity to meet loads of people.
job_title: Student Ambassador in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: You get to meet a wide range of very interesting people ranging all ages. The university has a very strong ethos when it comes to student experience and environmental practice.
cons: A single payment method instead of constantly having to fill in financial details.

job_title: Power Systems Engineer in London, England
pros: nice place, lots of smart people, good research environment, good device, experienced staff, nice lab. I am very enjoy study and work there. big project
cons: nice place, lots of smart people, good research environment, good device, experienced staff, nice lab. I am very enjoy study and work there. big project

job_title: Research Visitor in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: You are given all the tools you need to develop your job. Everyone believes in you and all the colleagues are very friendly.
cons: The weather. Apart from that, there are not many Cons. They care about you and you feel you are contributing to something. Everyone as the same aim.

job_title: Desktop Support Analyst in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Generous salary vs. skillset & experience. Vast amount of lateral movement internally. State of the art software & hardware.
cons: The “Old Guard” needs to accept change. In the same breath, the much higher ups need to stop using buzzwords for no reasons and start being transparent about potential restructures.

review_title: A University I'm mostly proud to work for
job_title: Curriculum Development Officer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Committed to contributing to the region and community, strives to focus on connecting to students, tries to make a difference
cons: Like lots of Unis, can be hierarchical and slow to adapt. Is not always consistent in providing staff resourcing in line with student support commitments.

job_title: Research Associate in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: As any UK University - nice job if you can get it, the city is cheap and cheerful.
cons: Unfortunately, FLS is not interested in retaining and/or retraining people, which already work for them preferring to use them and replace as short-term goals dictate.

job_title: Research Fellow in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: A friendly environment, great supervision, sense of community
cons: Some frustrating administrative systems (size matters)

review_title: Faculty ignores the people that do the work
job_title: Senior Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Great city, great students. Good Uni
cons:
Faculty don't really care about what happens. Poor communication, pretend meetings were opinions are asked for, but a decision has clearly been made.

The recent reorganisation of Sage was a prime example.

job_title: Student Ambassador in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: It is very good to work with internationally reputed organisation. The team is of international personals. They are very helpful and friendly people.
cons: The upper management does not seems to be care about people working for them, which happens in all the big reputed organisations.

job_title: in Newcastle, England
pros: Definitely a great way of earning money alongside studies.
cons: Some of the jobs can be a bit boring but you can always choose not to do the boring ones!

job_title: Research Assistant in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
- Employees feel really valued and are offerrd great opportunities
- Competitive university in terms of rankings and research
- Salaries relatively competitive in comparison to the average in the area
- Great infrastructure (depending on the department)
cons: -Worklife balance might be compromised, depending on the department

job_title: Part Time Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Great service departments for teaching staff, especially IT.
cons: Extremely heavy workload with too much emphasis on 'the student is a customer'.

job_title: Open Day Ambassador in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Great hourly pay, high working flexibility and relatively stress-free
cons: Limited availability of work assignments as it depends when the university hosts open days or post-applicant days. Sometimes the work itself can be boring but that depends on the specific role of the ambassador

job_title: Human Resources in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Pretty forward looking and relaxed. Good prospects going forward with investments made for foreign students.
cons: Some of the employees are true bean counters and some of the most inefficient and petty people I have ever met.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newcastle, England
pros:
- investment in staff development
- keen interest in staff welfare with support available
- job security through strong financial management
- pension still attractive despite recent changes
cons:
- career paths could be stronger / more developed in areas
- longevity-based pay progression rather than contribution-based

job_title: PhD Student in Newcastle, England
pros: flexibility, plenty of collaborations, high tech equipment, core facilities with experts, free language courses and good career advisors
cons: inattentive HR, no good/healthy food in campus, convoluted bureaucracy for everything, flat city life (if you are not interested in pubs and drinks)

job_title: PhD Student in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: many learning opportunities and spaces for study or work with flexible hours
cons: the various buildings are dispersed in a very large area, often it takes a while to figure out where to go, the university map is not really helpfull

job_title: Secretary in Newcastle, England
pros: It has a good atmosphere and had good rapport with colleagues. Had a good work/life balance and benfits were fine. Great to get the experience.
cons: Career prospects could have been better for the grade that I was on.

job_title: Technician in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Some good people left but many have been politiced out of the door.  Good location.
cons: Sadly has been taken over by a combination of the Peter principle, the Dilbert principle and the Dunning Kreuger effect.  This is now so firmly entrenched that the only way to become part of the next generation of mangement is on the coattails of the current generation.

job_title: MSC Student in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Global aspect of the industry and good approach of it's specialities
cons: Many external Lecturers. The course was largely related to pipeline engineering

review_title: the resource environment is very friendly
job_title: PhD Researcher in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: personal growth is very fast, promotion is very big, and newcastle is very suitable for living
cons: the training is comparatively less.

job_title: Technician in Newcastle, England
pros: Good management, clear salary progression, city location
cons: Large organisation so you can feel a bit anonymous

job_title: EAP Tutor in Newcastle, England
pros: It was in the UK, offering very good salaries, Flexible teaching time, good working environment, friendly teaching staff and overall, a well-reputed University
cons: I worked on a contract-based jobs

job_title: Senior Administrator in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Flexible working, supportive of mental health and well being, good pay and training opportunities
cons: Hard to progress sometimes, can need to jump through hoops for promotions

review_title: The pay was really good and it was a healthy atmosphere
job_title: Desk Coordinator (Student ResLife Job) in Newcastle, England
pros: The pay was really good and it was a healthy atmosphere
cons: There was no furlough scheme during lockdown

review_title: Great job for when you're a student
job_title: Student Ambassador in Newcastle, England
pros:
-Great pay
-Good management
-Many opportunities and easy to work around studying
cons: -Not a regular influx of working opportunities- you couldn't use this job to try pay rent

job_title: Research Assistant Part-time in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Time flexible, good social environment, great research team, city is very beautiful, good public transport environment.
cons: bureaucracy, lack of career pathway, slow financial processing system, slow university process system.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Good place to study Chemical Engineering, as it offers a good insight into the key principles of the subject.
cons: Study spaces could be improved. However this is in the process.

job_title: Research Assistant in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Good pay, treat staff well, good holidays, can work from home depending on role, can get discounts on courses
cons: I can't think of any cons.

review_title: Great place to  work and study
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in Newcastle upon Tyne, England

cons: Frequent reorganisations take too much effort and time from the employees

job_title: in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Best decision to come to study in Newcastle as is one of the most organised and structured university with a perfect career service
cons: Nothing wrong with the university

job_title: Research Associate in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Stimulating environment, very much like a medium size enterprise
cons: Being part of much competitive cluster (Russel Group), Newcastle University stress the importance of produce excellent outcome from our research

job_title: Lab Demonstrator in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Decent pay, friendly environment, good facilities, opportunity to learn on the job, no undue pressure
cons: The job can only be carried out during term time.

job_title: PhD Student in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Good work/life balance with the University being in the city centre
cons: Despite the semblance of formal processes, one's academic performance is governed by the opinion of one's supervisor.

job_title: Research Assistant in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Lot of research to get invoved with and staff support
cons: Large institution that you sometimes dont easily connect except you get out of your desk to attend seminars

job_title: Computer Lab Aide in Newcastle upon Tyne, England

job_title: PDRA in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Engineering faculty enables collaborative work among different schools which is also advantageous due to a varied equipment availability.

job_title: Student Ambassador in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Attractive salary (particularly for students), and competitive benefits

review_title: health, safety and business continuity manager
